id_table_1.caption: TABLE I: A tally of widely-used human pose and shape datasets, compared in terms of number of subjects (Sub), number of different actions (Act), multi-modality (MM), number of RGB (RGB) and depth (Depth) frames, availability of annotated poses (P) and shapes (S) for each frame.
table:
Dataset Sub Act MM RGB Depth P S
MS COCO [61] - - ✗ 330K ✗ 2D ✗
MPII [39] - - ✗ 40K ✗ 2D ✗
PoseTrack [62] - - ✗ 22K ✗ 2D ✗
MPI-3DHP [33] 8 - ✗ 1.3M ✗ 3D ✗
3DPW [63] 7 8 ✗ 51K ✗ 3D ✓
Human3.6M [32] 11 15 ✗ 3.6M 0.45M 3D ✗
PHSPD (ours) 21 31 ✓ 2.1M 2.1M 3D ✓
footnotes:
[61] [61]

T.-Y. Lin, M. Maire, S. Belongie, J. Hays, P. Perona, D. Ramanan,
P. Dollár, and C. L. Zitnick, “Microsoft coco: Common objects in
context,” in ECCV, 2014.

[63] [63]

[32] [32]

C. Ionescu, D. Papava, V. Olaru, and C. Sminchisescu, “Human3.6m: Large scale

Intelligence, vol. 36, no. 7, pp. 1325–1339, 2014.

id_table_2.caption: TABLE II: Quantitative evaluations of surface normal estimation on SfP dataset [27]. MAE is reported in the case of six scenes and the whole set. HumanSfP2 (ours) outperforms two baseline methods [71, 27] by a large margin. It also demonstrates that our new method, HumanSfP2 (ours) outperforms the previous effort, HumanSfP1 [31], especially in the cases of complex shapes such as Horse and Dragon.
table:
Scene HeightfP [71] DeepSfP [27] HumanSfP1 [31] HumanSfP2 (ours)
Dragon 49.16 21.55 18.71 16.88
Horse 55.87 22.27 21.27 19.64
Christmas 39.68 13.50 8.56 8.57
Box 31.00 23.31 21.94 22.04
Flamingo 36.05 20.19 20.51 20.44
Vase 36.88 10.32 9.20 9.18
Whole Set 41.44 18.52 17.22 16.73
footnotes:

W. A. Smith, R. Ramamoorthi, and S. Tozza, “Height-from-polarisation with
unknown lighting or albedo,” IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and
Machine Intelligence, vol. 41, no. 12, pp. 2875–2888, 2018.

id_table_3.caption: TABLE III: Quantitative evaluation of surface normal estimation on SURREAL and PHSPD datasets in terms of MAE. HumanSfP2 (ours) significantly outperforms the three baseline methods.

id_table_4.caption: TABLE IV: Quantitative evaluations of human pose estimation on both SURREAL and PHSPD datasets. The unit of joint error is in millimeter. HMR [20] and SPIN [54] take RGB images (C) as the input, while HMR (polar), HumanSfP1 [31] and HumanSfP2 (ours) take polarization images (P) as the input.
